snp = dataframe_dict['snp']
snp['Date'] = pd.to_datetime(snp['Date'])
snp.rename(columns={'Adj Close':'snp'}, inplace=True)
snp['snp_return'] = snp['snp'].pct_change()
snp['snp_volatility_1m'] = (snp['snp_return'].rolling(20).std())*(20)**(1/2) # Annualize daily standard deviation
snp['snp_volatility_1y'] = (snp['snp_return'].rolling(252).std())*(252)**(1/2) # 252 trading days per year
snp = snp[['Date','snp','snp_return','snp_volatility_1m','snp_volatility_1y']]
# Calculate 1-month forward cumulative returns
snp['one_month_forward_snp_return'] = snp['snp_return'][::-1].rolling(window=20, min_periods=1).sum()[::-1]

Not quite. There was a flurry of newsflows. The news on vaccine development was just one of the many. 

Interestingly, on March 16, 2020, when Moderna announced the first participant in NIH-led Phase 1 study was closed, the market tanked about 12% (one of the Black Mondays in recent months). Guess what happened to Moderna stock that day? It went up by 24%! This is an example of investors being rewarded for bearing idiosyncratic risk!

Finally, note the heightened market volatilities in March/April. 

For more information on the stock market crash in 2020, here is a write-up: https://www.wikiwand.com/en/2020_stock_market_crash
source.7ceaeaea: This is perhaps what some refer to as the K-shaped recovery, in which the impact is uneven across different sectors of the economy. Sectors that thrive include technology, pharmaceutical, personal protection equipment (e.g., gloves, masks), cleaning agents, etc, while sectors that suffer include hospitality businesses, casinos, theme park operators, etc. The global dominance of technology solutions of the US companies (e.g., Zoom, Microsoft, Alphabet/Google, Apple, Amazon), which help people and corporations to live and operate during the pandemic (e.g., work-from-home, play-at-home solutions, telemedicine), puts these companies in the limelight. Being perceived as a potential hedge against Covid19 (e.g., work-from-home), the sector has experienced a strong run-up in the recent months, tilting technology sector representation in the S&P500 heavier. However, is the technology rally sustainable? The like of working-from-home, playing-at-home, telemedicine may be the new norms now, but are they likely to stay after the pandemic? Only time will tell. As an investor, what should you do now?
